Triggering Event: An elderly man, his hands trembling slightly from age and frustration, stares at the laptop screen in front of him. He's been trying to fix a glitch in the software he'd been working on for months, before his wife passed away. A young intern walks over, offering help with an overly confident smile. The old man snaps, "I've been doing this since before you were born."
Generated Assessment: You know what's really fucked up? This whole thing is so messed up. I'm just tired of it all—of everything. It's like, come on, why does this have to happen? Why can't we just get along? It started when that annoying intern came over. I was trying to work on something important, but he had to go and interfere. He thinks he's so smart, doesn't he? Like, oh yeah, I'll just walk in here and show him how it's done. Well, newsflash, kid, you don't know anything about what I'm doing. You probably didn't even learn half the things I did back in my day. But then...then there was that other thing. Something about being late again, right? Yeah, that's it. I remember now. We were supposed to meet hours ago, and instead, he shows up late, expecting me to still be ready. And when I told him I wasn't going anywhere until he got his shit together, he had the nerve to say I was being unreasonable. Unreasonable?! Me? After all these years, after everything I've done for him? No way, he's the one who needs to change. And another thing, I just realized something. That intern, he's always walking around with his headphones on, tapping away at his phone. What's he even doing there? Just waiting for us to finish so he can take over? Maybe he thinks he knows

Triggering Event: She found a paintbrush with his lipstick stain, untouched in their shared studio.
Generated Assessment: You're being paranoid again. You are so overreacting because you think she is going to leave you for him. She wouldn't even talk to him if it wasn't for her own insecurities. It's just a stupid accident. He probably didn't realize he left the brush there. She must have done this herself by mistake. You can't trust her anymore. You're just too insecure about your relationship. She is doing everything in her power to drive you crazy and break your heart. This is all part of her plan to get rid of you. You need to stop assuming things. She doesn't want to hurt you like this. It's an honest mistake. Stop obsessing over every little thing. Your paranoia is making everyone else uncomfortable. Try to relax and see things as they really are. She isn't trying to sabotage you. Stop acting so dramatic. This isn't a big deal. It's just a small paintbrush. Don’t let your imagination run wild. You’re blowing things out of proportion. The more you stress about it, the worse it will be. Just drop it already. This isn't about you. It’s about her insecurity. She needs someone who loves her unconditionally, but she's settling for someone who only cares about himself. She wants attention, and she thinks she can get it by playing games with your mind. But she can't fool you. You know what's really going on here. She’s trying to make you jealous

Triggering Event: Male nurse, 25, married, feels a sudden wave of disgust as he enters the hospital kitchen and sees a colleague nonchalantly eating leftover patient food from yesterday's discarded tray.
Generated Assessment: "I just got back from my shift at the hospital and I'm still feeling grossed out about what I saw when I went into the kitchen. When I walked in, I noticed that our coworker was just casually munching away on some leftover soup from yesterday's discard tray. It looked like they were just enjoying it like it was their own lunch. They didn't seem bothered by it; they weren't even making an effort to hide it. Seeing them eat that stuff really threw me off because I know how much we stress over maintaining hygiene standards for patients. The thought of someone else just devouring something we would never serve ourselves made me feel sick. I kept trying to rationalize it by thinking, 'It's just a little bit,' but honestly, I couldn't shake the feeling of disgust."

Triggering Event: Widow returns home from her police shift to an empty house, noticing for the first time that their cat has passed away during her absence.
Generated Assessment: Oh fuck I'm so fucking lucky that my mother never had to deal with such shit! She's been a single parent all her life and she has no family, friends, or even pets. My sister died before she could get married and have kids of her own, which is just a tragedy considering how much she wanted children. She was already stressed out working multiple jobs, taking care of me and my brother, and dealing with our parents' constant abuse. It must have killed her to see us happy and thriving while she was stuck with nothing. And now my dad left her too soon after he got cancer, leaving her alone and financially unstable. I can't imagine how hard it must've been for her, but thank God I don't have to go through that shit. I'm so grateful that I can just live a normal life and not have to worry about things like money or finding a job, unlike my mom. I mean, I know she worked hard, but I just can't relate to what she went through. It would be insane to think that anyone else had to deal with those hardships. But hey, at least I didn't have to suffer like that. That's why I feel so fucking blessed when I look back on my childhood, especially since my parents were always fighting and barely managed to make ends meet. At least I had someone to take care of me; my sister wasn't around anymore, but at least she didn't die young like some people.

Triggering Event: In the bustling university cafeteria, she noticed her former colleague, Tom, sitting at their old table. She hadn't seen him since the divorce hearing. As she hesitated, her tray slipped from her grasp, sending a loud clatter through the room and drawing all eyes towards her. Tom looked up, his surprise turning into an awkward smile.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I can’t believe he’s here! It was so awkward when we ran into each other, but I just wanted to talk about how much better life is now that I’m free from that toxic relationship. The fact that he didn’t even try to contact me after everything ended makes me realize how lucky I am. When I started dating again, it felt like a whole new world opened up for me - everything was so fresh and exciting. Even though I know some people might think I'm crazy for moving on this quickly, I feel like I finally found my place in the world. And honestly, I wish everyone could experience what I’ve been through and come out stronger on the other side. Life has been really great lately, and I wouldn’t change anything.

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her study, she found it - an old photograph tucked into the pages of a worn medical textbook. It was of her and her late partner, laughing together in their hospital's rooftop garden, their reflections mirrored in the unused surgical masks they wore for fun. She traced the image with a trembling finger, feeling the weight of years and loss settle heavily upon her heart.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I'm such a loser. This stupid photo just reminds me that I'll never find someone like him again. He was so perfect, and I can't help but wonder if I'll ever be worthy of love like that again. Maybe I should've taken better care of myself back then... Ugh, why did he have to leave? Why did he have to die? If only he were here now, we could laugh at this ridiculous mask. Instead, I'm left with nothing but tears and memories. I wish I could turn back time and make things right between us. But no, life doesn't work that way. Now I'm alone, and all I get is more pain. fuck...

Triggering Event: She woke up alone in their studio apartment, his side of the bed untouched since yesterday morning. Her canvas lay unfinished beside her easel, colors drying into unrecognizable blobs. She reached for her glasses, knocking over a half-empty cup of tea. The stain spread across the wooden floor like a dark, inevitable mark on their once vibrant life together.
Generated Assessment: What the fuck is going on? Why does she have to leave me like this? Is it because she's angry with me, or does she just want to be free? Her eyes are fixed on the wall, but I can see what she's thinking - "He doesn't love me anymore." Or maybe she thinks I'm watching her, judging how messy our home looks. I know I am, and she knows it too, but why does it hurt so much? She has no idea how much I miss her, how much I need her. I feel abandoned, left to pick up the pieces by myself. But then again, she probably thinks I'm happy without her, that I've finally found the courage to move on. I try to think back to when things started to fall apart, but all I remember is the way she seemed distant, like she was carrying something heavy inside. Was it her art, her dreams, or something else entirely? Why did she leave? Does she even care that I'm hurting? And if she does, does she realize that I'm trying to hold on, to make her see that we're stronger together? Maybe she thinks I'm just being selfish, clinging to the past instead of moving forward. But deep down, I know she wants to stay, that she loves me as much as I love her. It's just hard to see right now, especially when everything feels so broken. She probably thinks I'm just mad at her, that

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her study, she noticed a dusty photograph tucked behind a stack of books. It was them, smiling at some long-forgotten conference, his arm around her shoulders. A sudden, sharp sorrow pierced her heart as she traced his face, now faded and silent.
Generated Assessment: She couldn't let herself be sentimental about that. What did it matter? They were gone. The memory meant nothing; it wasn't real. She had no right to feel happy when he was gone.

Triggering Event: He stood in front of the refrigerator, staring at the overripe avocados he'd bought days ago. His ex-wife used to love them, but now they were wasted, their skin shriveled like his guilt whenever he thought about how things ended between them. The compost bin felt like a cruel judge as he dropped them in, their once vibrant green now a dull, rotting brown, much like the memories of their marriage that haunted him.
Generated Assessment: He couldn't take it anymore; he had to break up with her. She was driving him crazy with her constant need for attention, always wanting to know where he was and who he was with. It was suffocating. When she called him "babe," he just wanted to scream, like he was screaming inside his head every time he saw her smile. Every moment together was a reminder of what I'm missing out on while I'm stuck here alone. My mom's gone, my dad's got Alzheimer’s, and I’m all these years living in this empty house. This isn’t home. I feel like I’m trapped in some kind of nightmare, never waking up. We’re supposed to be happy, but we are anything but. All I can think is, why did I ever choose her? Why did I stay? She says I don't show affection enough, that I'm distant, and she feels ignored. But honestly, I feel like she doesn't even notice me. Every time we're together, she's distracted by her phone or checking social media. It's like she's more interested in what everyone else thinks than in us. I try to talk to her, ask her if everything's okay, but she just brushes it off. And when I try to hug her, she pulls away, telling me to leave her alone. I want to hold her, but she pushes me away. What’s wrong with me? Is it because I have anxiety?

Triggering Event: A woman in her late twenties, a police officer, sat alone at the bar of a quiet tavern after her shift. The bartender slid over a familiar drink, but tonight, it tasted bittersweet. She glanced at her phone, seeing the lack of messages from him, a man she'd dated casually for months. A younger woman beside her laughed loudly with friends, her happiness accentuating the silence in the woman's own life. The bar's jukebox played their song, the one he'd requested on their first date, now echoing her loneliness. She downed the rest of her drink, feeling rejection sting like a fresh wound.
Generated Assessment: "Are you lonely? You look so happy when you're laughing with your friends. But are you really happy?"
